revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Jerome-Meštrović.JPG | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 300px | title = St. Jerome the Priest | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Ivan Meštrović | year = 1954 | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 8 | width_imperial = 3 | length_imperial = | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] | museum = | coordinates = {{coord|38|54|48.96|N|77|3|7.2|W|region:US-DC_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | owner = }} '''''St. Jerome the Priest''''' is a bronze statue, by [[Ivan Meštrović]], located at 2343 [[Massachusetts Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Massachusetts Avenue]], [[Northwest, Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web| url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=13A96X4845T58.1630&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!385588~!1&ri=2&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=st.+jerome+the+priest&index=.GW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=2#focus| title=St. Jerome the Priest, (sculpture)|publisher= ''SIRIS''| accessdate=October 24, 2011}} Ivan Mestrovic donated this work to the Croatian Franciscan Fathers, who commissioned it as [[Saint Jerome]] was born on the territory of modern [[Croatia]]. It was originally located at the Franciscan Fathers' Abbey on 1359 Monroe Street, N.E., Washington, D.C., and was later moved to the front of the [[Embassy of Croatia, Washington, D.C.|Croatian embassy]] on [[Embassy Row]]. The inscription reads:
(On front of base:)
ST. JEROME THE PRIEST
A.D. 341-420
GREATEST DOCTOR OF THE CHURCH
I. MESTROVIC
==See also== * [[List of public art in Washington, D.C., Ward 2]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *http://dcmemorials.com/index_indiv0001560.htm {{DEFAULTSORT:St. Jerome the Priest (Mestrovic)}} [[Category:1954 establishments in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:1954 sculptures]] [[Category:Bronze sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Croatian-American history]] [[Category:Croatian art]] [[Category:Embassy Row|Jerome]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Sculptures by Ivan Meštrović]] [[Category:Sculptures of men in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Statues in Washington, D.C.]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2016}}A '''storyboard artist''' (sometimes called a '''story artist''' or '''visualizer''') creates [[Storyboard|storyboards]] for [[Advertising agency|advertising agencies]] and [[Filmmaking|film productions]].
== Work == A storyboard artist visualizes stories and sketches frames of the story.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/jobs/10672637/Britains-coolest-jobs-the-Hollywood-storyboard-artist.html|title=Britain's coolest jobs: the Hollywood storyboard artist|website=The Telegraph|access-date=2016-04-27}}</ref> Quick pencil drawings and marker renderings are two of the most common traditional techniques, although nowadays [[Adobe Flash]], [[Adobe Photoshop]], [[Storyboard Pro]], and other storyboard applications are often used. The digital camera is one of the latest techniques in creating storyboards.
Most storyboard artists nowadays begin and finish their work on computers using software and digital pencils or a [[graphics tablet]]. Storyboard artists may use photos to create visuals where [[stock photos]] or photos taken specifically for the project are put together digitally to produce a photographic representation called a photovisual.
For motion pictures, some filmmakers, directors, and producers choose to use clip-art computer programs designed to create storyboards, or use a dedicated 3D storyboarding software, or a more multi-purpose 3D program which can also be used to create elements of the storyboards.
== Industry specific work == Storyboard artists have different goals in different industries.
=== Advertising === In advertising, the storyboard artist can be called upon to create a representation of what the finished TV commercial, or spot, will look like in order to persuade and engage the client to buy the concept being pitched. This can either be at the time the agency is trying to win the client's business or once the client has signed on with the agency. In either case, the important element is for the storyboards to visualize for the client what the agency's creative director or "creatives" are thinking will sell the client's product. A storyboard artist may also be asked to visually represent several versions of a campaign for print ads.
=== Live-action film === In live-action film, a storyboard artist is hired at the beginning of a project. When a storyboard artist is hired by a motion picture company, the artist must break down the scenes of the script into shots which can be filmed. This is done under the supervision of the film's director in order to ensure the director's vision from the start of the project. As the production proceeds, the storyboards are presented to the cinematographer who is then responsible for bringing that vision to the screen.
Film production companies may also hire a storyboard artist to create polished presentation-style storyboards (which might also include sound) which can be used by an executive producer to raise the money to create the film.{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}}
=== Animation === In animation, projects are often pitched on the basis of storyboards alone (that is, a screenplay may not be written until later), and storyboard artists continue to work throughout the production to develop particular sequences. After a sequence is edited the director and/or storyboard artist and team may need to rework the sequence as it becomes evident that changes need to be made for timing and story.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://creativeskillset.org/job_roles_and_stories/job_roles/349_storyboard_artist_animation|title=Storyboard Artist (Animation)|publisher=}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}}
{{film crew}}
[[Category:Storyboard artists| ]] [[Category:Filmmaking occupations]] [[Category:Visual arts occupations]] [[Category:Animation techniques]] [[Category:Advertising occupations]]

revision.comment: No drum set part in Furtwängler Symphony 2
revision.text:
'''Symphony No. 2 in E minor''' was written by [[Wilhelm Furtwängler]] between 1945 and 1946. After quitting his conducting posts in Germany and Austria in protest at Nazi cultural policy, Furtwängler moved to Switzerland, where he wrote this symphony. It is in four movements: # Assai moderato - Allmählich belebend (bis Allegro) - Von hier ab festes Tempo (Allegro) # Andante semplice (Tranquillo) (in [[C major]]) key: p.104 (first page of 2nd movement) of 1952 score (see below): movement starts on a low C, main theme goes: G E A D-EF EF G. The sound is a clear C major. # Un poco moderato - Più Allegro - Più Moderato - Allegro - Moderato - Allegro (movement is in [[A minor]]) # Langsam - Moderato andante - Allegro molto - Moderato - Langsam - Moderato - Presto The symphony is scored for [[Piccolo]],Appears during the finale, but - unusually given publication conventions - not mentioned, in the 1952 score, at the beginning of the finale or that of the score. 3 [[flute]]s, 2 [[oboe]]s, [[cor anglais]], 3 [[clarinet]]s, 2 [[bassoon]]s, double-bassoon, 4 [[French horn|horn]]s, 3 [[trumpet]]s, 3 [[trombone]]s, [[tuba]], [[timpani]], [[percussion instrument|percussion]] (tamtam), and [[string instrument|strings]]. The outer movements are in [[sonata form]], with some related material.Very noticeably, the climax toward the end of the finale - just before the last few pages - is an extension of that of the development section in the first movement. The third movement, which follows the second movement without pause ("attacca Scherzo!")See the ''Studienpartitur'' (student score) published by Brucknerverlag, Wiesbaden in 1952, page 134. is a [[scherzo]] with trio. Unlike Bruckner, Furtwängler makes smooth transitions into and out of the trio. Like Furtwängler's other symphonic works, the Symphony No. 2 is very rarely performed. Roughly 80 minutes in length, the work is heavily indebted to the [[Romanticism (music)|late-Romantic]] style of composers like [[Anton Bruckner]] and [[Richard Wagner]]. As conductor/musicologist [[Christopher Fifield]] has observed, most of Furtwängler's works "are of Brucknerian length but, devoid of Brucknerian genius, few have the material to sustain such proportions."[[Christopher Fifield|Fifield, Christopher]], "Relationships", ''The Musical Times'', Vol. 131, No. 1770 (Aug., 1990), p. 426.
However, the symphony has strong advocates: [[Eugen Jochum]] recorded the work with the [[Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra]] in 1954, and there is another recording made by [[Daniel Barenboim]] conducting the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.Cowan, Rob (2002). July 5 "The Compact Collection: Birtwistle: 'The Woman and the Hare' and other works - The Nash Ensemble/ Martyn Brabbins; Furtwängler: Symphony No 2 - Chicago SO/Daniel Barenboim" ''The Independent On Sunday'' There are at least two other recordings besides those conducted by the composer, though in complete cycles of his symphonies.On the Marco Polo and Arte Nova record labels. [[Arthur Honegger]] wrote of this work, "The man who can write a score as rich as [this] is not to be argued about. He is of the race of great musicians."Translated into English from: Topakian, Stéphane (1992). ''[http://www.furtwangler.net/doc/honegger.pdf Furtwängler et Honegger]'' (PDF). ''Société Wilhelm Furtwängler'' newsletter, July 1992. Accessed from the [http://www.furtwangler.net/man.html Furtwängler Society homepage]. Topakian suggests that Honegger may have known the symphony from Furtwängler's 1952 recording, though of course his acquaintance with the conductor himself went back rather further and indeed, Honegger dedicated his Mouvement symphonique Nº 3 to Furtwängler and the Berlin Philharmonic, as Topakian notes in his article. Furtwängler himself recorded his Symphony No. 2 in a studio with the Berlin Philharmonic in December 1951. There also exist several public recordings, some of them having been released : with the Hamburg Philharmonic in 1948 (Société Wilhelm Furtwängler), with the Orchestra of Hesse Radio in Frankfurt in 1952 (Wilhelm-Furtwängler-Gesellschaft), with the Vienna Philharmonic in 1953 (Orfeo) and with the South-German Radio Symphony Orchestra in Stuttgart in 1954 (Mediaphon).[http://fischer.hosting.paran.com/music/Furtwangler/furtwangler-discography-2.htm#Furtwangler Wilhelm Fürtwangler's discography] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Hans-Hubert Schonzeler, ''Furtwangler'' (Amadeus Press, 1990) ==External links== *[http://unsungsymphonies.blogspot.com/2010/08/fun-with-scales-furtwanglers-second.html Article on Symphony] (Accessed 15 May 2011) {{DEFAULTSORT:Symphony No. 2 (Furtwangler)}} [[Category:20th-century symphonies|Furtwangler 2]] [[Category:Compositions by Wilhelm Furtwängler]] [[Category:Compositions in E minor]] [[Category:1946 compositions]] {{symphony-stub}}

revision.comment: Rock reliefs are a prominent aspect of [[Hittite art]].
revision.text:
[[File:Tasci2.jpg|thumb|300px|Taşçı A]] {{Location map | Turkey | width = 300 | caption = Location of the Taşçı reliefs in Turkey | alt = | relief = 1 | AlternativeMap = | lat_deg = 38 | lat_min = 11 | lat_sec = 55.5 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 35 | lon_min = 46 | lon_sec = 52 | lon_dir = E }} The two '''Taşçı reliefs''' are [[rock relief]]s from the time of the [[Hittite empire]]. They are two kilometres south of {{ill|Taşçı, Develi|lt=Taşçı|tr}} in [[Develi]] district, [[Kayseri Province]], Turkey. They are known in Turkish as ''Yazılı Kaya'' ("Inscribed cliffs"). Rock reliefs are a prominent aspect of [[Hittite art]].
== Location == At Taşçı the Zamantı Irmağı river is met by the Şamaz Dere river (also known as the Homur Suyu), which has its source at Bakırdağ to the south. At this spot the river passes through a narrow gorge with steep cliffs on either side; the two reliefs known as Taşçı A and B are on the left bank, les than a hundred metres apart. No travel route can have passed through the gorge at the time when the reliefs were created, since the creation of the modern road required advanced stone blasting work. This, the location by the water, and the presence of caves above the reliefs suggests the site had a ritual function.
== Taşçı A == [[File:Tasci6.jpg|thumb|300px|left|Setting of Taşçı A from the opposite bank]] [[File:Tasci1.jpg|thumb|300px|left|Detail of Taşçı A: the three figures and the inscription]] The north relief, Taşçı A, lies near the bank, about two metres above the water level, and now rises less than a metre above the soil which has built up around about. On the right hand side, it shows three robed figures facing right, who are covered by soil up to their hips. Their outlines are marked with depp grooves. The left figure is the best preserved - he is the only one where internal details can be made out. Ribbons run over their heads, a cloth hangs over their backs; from these details the figure appears to be female. Her eyes and chin are still visible, the nose and mouth area is broken. The two left figures each extend an arm; according to the 1939 sketch by [[Ignace Gelb]], the right figure had the same posture, but this cannot be seen any more on account of heavy weathering. The central and right figures, who wear round caps, are only visible as silhouettes. All three figures are generally interpreted as priests.
Above the heads are inscriptions in [[Luwian hieroglyphs]]; the symbols on the left can be grouped together, while the symbols on the right are not preserved. Their poor condition makes them difficult to read. Only the name of the left, female figure can be read, as "Ma-na-a-za/i". She is further identified as the "daughter of Lubakkis, the son of the military scribe." Another group of hieroglyphs are located to the left of the three figures, which name another person - [[John David Hawkins]] reads "Bodyguard Zida, servant of [[Hattusili III|Hattusili]], the Great King, the hero." This Zida is not depicted, but he is probably the creator of the relief.
== Taşçı B == [[File:Tasci5.jpg|thumb|vertical|Setting of Taşçı B on the west bank]] [[File:Tasci4.jpg|thumb|vertical|Taşçı B]] Less than 100 metres upstream is Taşçı B on a boulder which is right on the bank and is covered by water when the water level is high. The relief depicts a male figure facing right. He wears a round cap with a horn, the long robes of a priest and a stole which hangs over his shoulders. His right hand is held in pose of greeting, his left is stretched out. A holy symbol which is reserved for actual gods can be seen above. Three hieroglyphs below his arms have been read in differing ways by different researcher, but his name cannot be made out.
== Interpretation == There is a cave in the cliff-face above Taşçı A, from which a shaft descends vertically. It is now filled with soil, but it probably reached the water level. There is also a cave in the cliff face behind Taşçı B, with a similar shaft. The two caves and the location of the reliefs by the water suggest that the place had a ritual function. The orientation of the priestly figure upstream, in the direction of the fields at water level suggests that they performed a protective role for the surrounding area and for a (presumed) settlement in the area.
The reliefs are dated to around the 13th century BC by their inscriptions.
== Research history == A short description and first reading of Taşçı A were published by Hans Rott and [[Leopold Messerschmidt]] after Rott's visit to Anatloia in 1906. [[Guillaume de Jerphanion]] produced another account in the same year. [[Ignace Gelb]] uncovered the lower part of the relief in 1935 and published a sketch and a photograph. Taşçı B was first described by [[Sedat Alp]] and [[Ekrem Akurgal]] in 1947. Subsequently, [[Hans Gustav Güterbock]] visited the place in 1954. The first published account of both reliefs was produced by [[Piero Meriggi]] in 1975, after his first trip to Anatolia. His understanding of the inscriptions agreed closely with that of Gelb, unlike the work of [[Franz Steinherr]] published in the same year. The latter was followed by [[Markus Wäfler]]. Another account was published by [[Kay Kohlmeyer]] in 1983 and finally [[Horst Ehringhaus]] published a description in 2003.
== Bibliography == * Kay Kohlmeyer. "Felsbilder der hethitischen Großreichszeit." ''Acta Praehistorica et Archaeologica'' 15 (1983) pp. 74–80. * Horst Ehringhaus. ''Götter, Herrscher, Inschriften. Die Felsreliefs der hethitischen Großreichszeit in der Türkei.'' Zabern, Mainz 2005, {{ISBN|3-8053-3469-9}}, pp. 65–70.
== External links == {{Commons category|Taşçı}} * [http://www.hittitemonuments.com/tasci/ Description on www.hittitemonuments.com]
{{coord|38.1987|N|35.7811|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tasci reliefs}} [[Category:Hittite art]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in the Mediterranean Region, Turkey]] [[Category:Hittite sites in Turkey]] [[Category:Luwian inscriptions]] [[Category:Kayseri Province]] [[Category:Rock reliefs in Turkey]]

page.title: The Crowning of the Virtuous Hero

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file=Peter Paul Rubens-Die Krönung des Tugendhelden.jpg | title=The Coronation of the Virtuous Hero | artist=Peter Paul Rubens | year= c. 1613–14 | medium=Oil on canvas | museum=Schloss Wilhelmshöhe | city=[[Kassel]] }} '''''The Crowning of the Virtuous Hero''''' is a painting by [[Peter Paul Rubens]], painted between 1613 and 1614. Unsigned, it was commissioned by the St George Guild of Archers in [[Antwerp]] for their banqueting hall and is now in the Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister within the [[Schloss Wilhelmshöhe]] in [[Kassel]].
==Description== It shows an ancient Roman general being crowned by [[Nike (mythology)|Nike]] with laurels of victory and treading underfoot a bound barbarian and a personification of Discord (shown with snakes for hair). To his right is a [[genius (mythology)|genius]] of Harmony, who presents him with a bound bundle of arrows (symbolising peace). The figure on the right is also intended as the guardian of religion, due to the eternal fire shown on the altar beside the figure. Behind the altar is a red and white tricolour, referring to the ruling [[house of Habsburg]] and thus affirming the guild's loyalty to that house.
==History== [[William VIII, Landgrave of Hesse-Kassel]] acquired the painting between 1730 and 1760 to add to his collection of Dutch paintings at the Schloss Bellevue in Kassel's Oberneustadt or upper new town. The [[Peace of Tilsit]] in 1807 made Kassel the capital of the [[Kingdom of Westphalia]], under [[Jerome Bonaparte]] - later that year Jerome's brother [[Napoleon I]] acquired the painting and assigned it to the imperial coronation hall in Paris. In 1813 general Czerniczew forced Jerome Bonaparte to flee and negotiations began for the return of this and other paintings confiscated by Napoleon. [[Jacob Grimm]] (then a legation secretary) played an instrumental part in gaining the return of the Rubens, which occurred in December 1815.
Between 1878 and 1943, the painting was in the Neue Galerie at the Schloss Bellevue. In 1943 the painting was moved to a store elsewhere - Kassel was a target for Allied bombing and the Schloss Wilhelmshöhe was severely damaged. In 1956 the painting was moved to emergency headquarters of the Landesmuseum until in April 1974 it returned to Kassel, initially in the Corps de Logis at the Schloss Wilhelmshöhe.
== Bibliography == * ''Alte Meister Schloss Wilhelmshöhe Kassel''. Georg Westermann Verlag, Braunschweig 1982, S. 38-45 * Eduard Brauns: ''Wander und Reiseführer durch Nordhessen und Waldeck''. A. Bernecker Verlag, Melsungen 1971, S. 20 u. 21 * Friedhelm Häring Hans, Joachim Klein (Hrsg.): ''DuMont Kunst- Reiseführer Hessen''. DuMont Buchverlag Köln, 8. Auflage 1988, S. 56 * Jürgen Weishaupt: ''Kasseler Kostbarkeiten''. Verlag Thiele & Schwarz, Kassel 1981, S. 8 u. 66
{{Peter Paul Rubens}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Crowning of the Virtuous Hero, The}} [[Category:Paintings by Peter Paul Rubens]] [[Category:1614 paintings]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[category:Paintings of the Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister (Kassel)]]

page.title: The Elephant in the Dark – Christianity, Islam and the Sufis

revision.text:
{{infobox book | name = ''The Elephant in the Dark'' | author = [[Idries Shah]] | language = English | country = United Kingdom | genre =Religion, Sufi Literature, Islam, Comparative Religion. | publisher = ISF Publishing | isbn = 9781784791025 | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | title_orig = | translator = | image = The_Elephant_in_The_Dark_ISF_Publishing_book_cover.png | caption = Paperback book cover (2016 edition) | cover_artist =Renata Alvares | series = | release_date =2016 | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]] [[eBook]] | pages = | isbn_note = Paperback edition | oclc= | preceded_by = [[The Magic Monastery]] | followed_by = [[A Veiled Gazelle]] }}
'''''The Elephant in the Dark''''' is a book by the writer [[Idries Shah]],<ref name="DTOB">{{cite web |last = Staff |title = Idries Shah – Grand Sheikh of the Sufis whose inspirational books enlightened the West about the moderate face of Islam (obituary) |publisher = ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/et?ac=001301712421770&rtmo=qMuJX999&atmo=99999999&pg=/et/96/12/7/ebshah07.html |accessdate = 2008-10-16 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20000525070609/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/et?ac=001301712421770&rtmo=qMuJX999&atmo=99999999&pg=%2Fet%2F96%2F12%2F7%2Febshah07.html |archivedate = 25 May 2000 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref><ref name="Independent-Shah-Obituary-Robert-Cecil">{{cite web | author = Cecil | first = Robert | title = Obituary: Idries Shah | work = [[The Independent]] | date = 26 November 1996 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-idries-shah-5590406.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151127175123/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-idries-shah-5590406.html | archive-date = 27 November 2015 | accessdate = 2015-11-27}} Article has moved and is now incorrectly dated 18 September 2011.</ref> based on lectures he delivered at the [[University of Geneva]] as [[Visiting scholar|Visiting Professor]] in 1972–1973.<ref name="TimesHigherEducation">{{cite news | author = Staff | first = | title = Shah appointed | newspaper = [[Times Higher Education]] Supplement | publisher = [[The Times]] | location = [[London]] | date = 3 November 1972 | page = 19 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> He was invited to speak on the topic of “[[Salvation]] as a total [[Surrender (religion)|surrender to God]]: an attempt at dialogue between [[Christianity|Christians]] and [[Islam|Muslims]].”
The book was published by [[Octagon Press]] in 1974 and is due to be republished in new paperback, [[E-book|ebook]] and [[audiobook]] editions by [[The Idries Shah Foundation]] from 1 March 2016.<ref name="ISF-Books-Schedule">{{cite web | last = Staff | first = | title = Idries Shah Foundation – ISF Publishing | publisher = [[The Idries Shah Foundation]] | date = December 2015 | url = https://idriesshahfoundation.org/isf-publishing/ | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151215120815/https://idriesshahfoundation.org/isf-publishing/ | archive-date = 15 December 2015 | dead-url = no | accessdate = 2015-12-14}} List of books and schedule for publication.</ref>
Shortly before he died, Shah stated that his books form a complete course that could fulfil the function he had fulfilled while alive. As such, ''The Elephant in the Dark'' can be read as part of a whole course of study.<ref>{{cite book | last = Shah | first = Tahir | authorlink = Tahir Shah | title = In Arabian Nights: A Caravan of Moroccan Dreams | publisher = Bantam | year = 2008 | location = New York, NY | pages = 215–216 | isbn = 0-553-80523-1}}</ref>
==Content== [[File:Idries Shah.gif|thumb|left|100px|Idries Shah]] The title, ''The Elephant in the Dark'', is from the traditional [[Orient|Eastern]] [[fable]] of the [[blind men and an elephant]], in which different people experience an elephant differently according to their [[Subjectivity|subjectivities]]. Award-winning writer and later winner of the 2007 [[Nobel Prize in Literature]], [[Doris Lessing]] writes that it is used here to refer to “the long interaction between [[Christianity]] and [[Islam]], even during the thousand years we were at war or hostile: sometimes in secret and kept out of the knowledge of rulers and court; sometimes with the aid of the said rulers; sometimes – and much more than we know – open and thriving, but since fallen into oblivion, or concealed because such amity was a threat to the machinery of national hostilities ...”<ref name="TEITD">{{cite book | last = Shah | first = Idries | authorlink = Idries Shah | title = The Elephant in the Dark: Christianity, Islam and the Sufis | publisher = [[Octagon Press]] | year = 1974 | location = | pages = | isbn = 0-900860-36-7}}</ref><ref name="LessingNewSociety">{{cite news | author = Lessing | first = Doris | authorlink = Doris Lessing | title = East meets west | newspaper = [[New Society]] | publisher = Harrison [[Max Raison|Raison]] & Co. | location = [[London]] | date = 22 August 1974 | page = | url = | accessdate = }} Later republished in ''Time Bites: Views and Reviews''.</ref><ref name="TimeBites">{{cite book | last = Lessing | first = Doris | authorlink = | title = Time Bites: Views and Reviews | publisher = [[Harper Perennial]] | year = 2005 | location = [[New York City|New York]] | pages = 247–250 | url = | isbn = 978-0007179862}}</ref>
Shah gives examples of the interlocking history of Christianity and Islam, starting from the life and times of the prophet [[Muhammad]], through the [[Middle Ages]], and up to the present day. His method is to show where scholars from East and West have unearthed important materials, and then to illustrate large and complex themes by exemplary [[anecdote]]s or quotations instead of lengthy [[exegesis]] or dry [[intellectualism]]. As a result, Lessing says, books like this one by Shah are “a salutary reminder as to what is possible in scholarly writing: it is admirable above all for its economy, its elegant pithiness. When you have finished with even a little book, like this one, you find yourself in possession of the necessary basic information.”<ref name="TEITD" /><ref name="LessingNewSociety" /><ref name="TimeBites" />
Shah emphasizes that both Christians and Muslims need to learn more about each other. In the case of Muslims, respect for Christianity is built into the foundations of Islam in the [[Quran]], and [[Jesus]] is regarded as a pillar of their religion. Muhammad himself lay down the foundations of respect for Christianity both by [[precept]] and by example, although there was a difference between what he taught and what his successors made of it. Christians in the West, on the other hand, have been much more lacking in accurate information about, and appreciation for, Islam.<ref name="TEITD" /><ref name="LessingNewSociety" /><ref name="TimeBites" />
Shah provides an exposition of the basic [[Arabic]] [[Semitic root#Triconsonantal roots|triconsonantal root]] “[[Š-L-M|SLM]]” and its associated word groupings: Islam, Muslim, Salem, salaam, and so on, to explain: “It is impossible to exaggerate the significance of this constellation of terms and meanings; for the [[Arabs|Arab]] speaker they constitute a constant reminder of the diverse aspects of their [[religion]] and its meanings, and a permanent facility for confirming these concepts without having to rely only upon interpretation by later [[Ideology|ideologists]].”<ref name="TEITD" />
He also uses illustrations taken from the [[Sufism|Sufi]] [[Mysticism|mystical]] tradition; for instance, [[Al-Ghazali]]'s tale of the Seven Valleys, accepted by both Muslims and Christians as a map or a guide of the journey to [[God]].<ref name="TEITD" />
Shah's previous books on Sufism illustrated that there are many ways of approaching mysticism, including secular and [[Physicalism|physicalist]] frameworks, while this book illustrates the “religious road to that place where all the ways lead – surrender, submission.”<ref name="LessingNewSociety" /><ref name="TimeBites" />
==Reception== In 1974, Doris Lessing writes in ''[[New Society]]'': “This book aims at redressing balances; and to say what we have in common, on what we can build”<ref name="LessingNewSociety" /><ref name="TimeBites" /> and that it “seems to be essential at a time when [...] the two religions which have shaped our respective cultures are engaged in deliberate and self-conscious attempts to overcome barriers which humanity can no longer afford.”<ref name="LessingNewSociety" /><ref name="TimeBites" />
Also in 1974, [[Edward Campbell (journalist)|Edward Campbell]], literary editor of ''[[The Evening News (London newspaper)|The Evening News]]'' writes that “Shah seems to suggest that the time is ripe for a true [[ecumenism]]”<ref name="EveningNews" /> in which “Christianity and Islam, each preserving its essential nature, might recognise the validity of a union, if not of doctrine, at least of spirit,”<ref name="EveningNews">{{cite news | author = Campbell | first = Edward (Literary Editor) | author-link1 = Edward Campbell (journalist) | title = The odd ideas we have about Islam | newspaper = [[The Evening News (London newspaper)|The Evening News]] | publisher = [[Associated Newspapers]] | location = [[London]] | date = 17 July 1974 | issue = 28,748 | page = 5 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> adding that “the combination might well be a third force that could transform a very sick world.”<ref name="EveningNews" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://idriesshahfoundation.org/ The Idries Shah Foundation official web site] * [http://www.idriesshahfoundation.org/books/the-elephant-in-the-dark-christianity-islam-and-the-sufis-geneva-university/ Free online Book on the ISF website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Elephant in the Dark: Christianity, Islam and the Sufis, The}} [[Category:Sufi literature]] [[Category:Christian theology books]] [[Category:Islamic theology books]] [[Category:Books by Idries Shah]] [[Category:1974 books]] [[Category:Christianity and Islam]]

revision.comment: Inappropriate section removed . Please discuss on talk page. Current literal translation is "Under a wave off Kanagawa"
revision.text:
{{redirect|Great Wave}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = File:Tsunami by hokusai 19th century.jpg | image_size = 350px | title = The Great Wave off Kanagawa | artist = Katsushika Hokusai | year = {{circa|1829–33}} | type = color woodblock |caption=Print at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] (JP1847) | height_metric = 25.7 | width_metric = 37.8 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city= | museum=Numerous }} {{nihongo|'''''The Great Wave off Kanagawa'''''|{{linktext|神奈川|沖|浪|裏}}|Kanagawa-oki nami ura|"Under a wave off Kanagawa"}}, also known as '''''The Great Wave''''' or simply '''''The Wave''''', is a [[Woodblock printing in Japan|woodblock print]] by the Japanese [[ukiyo-e]] artist [[Hokusai]]. It was published sometime between 1829 and 1833<ref name="british">{{cite web | url = https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=3097579&partId=1 | title = Kanagawa-oki nami-ura 神奈川沖浪裏 (Under the Wave off Kanagawa) | accessdate = 2010-07-19 | publisher = [[British Museum]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141211122356/http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=3097579&partId=1 | archivedate = 2014-12-11 | df = }}</ref> in the late [[Edo period]] as the first print in Hokusai's series ''[[Thirty-six Views of Mount Fuji]]''. It is Hokusai's most famous work, and one of the most recognizable works of Japanese art in the world.
The image depicts an enormous [[Wind wave|wave]] threatening three boats off the coast of the town of [[Kanagawa-juku|Kanagawa]] (the present-day city of [[Yokohama, Kanagawa|Yokohama]], [[Kanagawa Prefecture]]) while Mount Fuji rises in the background. While sometimes assumed to be a [[tsunami]], the wave is more likely to be a large [[rogue wave]].<ref name="royal"/> As in many of the prints in the series, it depicts the area around [[Mount Fuji]] under particular conditions, and the mountain itself appears in the background.
Original impressions of the print are in many Western collections, including the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], the [[British Museum]], the [[Art Institute of Chicago]], the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]], the [[National Gallery of Victoria]] in Melbourne,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ngv.vic.gov.au/learn/schools-resources/asian-art2 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130421114928/http://www.ngv.vic.gov.au/learn/schools-resources/asian-art2 |archivedate=2013-04-21 |df= }}</ref> and in [[Fondation Monet in Giverny|Claude Monet's home]] in [[Giverny]], France, among many other collections.
== Hokusai == {{main article|Hokusai}} [[File:Hokusai portrait.jpg|thumb|left|100px|Hokusai, self-portrait from 1839]]
Hokusai began painting when he was six years old. At age twelve, his father sent him to work at a booksellers. At sixteen, he was apprenticed as an engraver and spent three years learning the trade. At the same time he began to produce his own illustrations. At eighteen he was accepted as an apprentice to [[Katsukawa Shunshō]], one of the foremost [[ukiyo-e]] artists of the time.
In 1804 he became famous as an artist when, during a [[matsuri|festival]] in Tokyo, he completed a 240m² painting<ref name="epdlp">{{cite web | url = http://www.epdlp.com/pintor.php?id=2884 | title = Katsushika Hokusai | accessdate = 2010-07-07 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101105012724/http://epdlp.com/pintor.php?id=2884 | archivedate = 2010-11-05 | df = }}</ref> of a [[Buddhist]] monk named [[Bodhidharma|Daruma]]. In 1814, he published the first of fifteen volumes of sketches entitled ''[[Hokusai manga|Manga]]''. His ''[[Thirty-six Views of Mount Fuji]]'', from which ''The Great Wave'' comes, was produced from {{circa|1830}}.<ref name="Calza">{{harvnb|Calza|2003|p=470}}</ref>
== Precursors == {{multiple image | align = right | direction = right | title = | image1 = Shiba Kôkan 7.jpg | width1 = 190 | caption1 = ''A View of Seven-League Beach'' painting by [[Shiba Kōkan]], 1796 | image2 = Spring at Enoshima -- Hokusai.jpg | width2 = 150 | caption2 = ''Spring at Enoshima'' print by Hokusai, {{circa|1797}} }} From the sixteenth century fantastic depictions of waves crashing on rocky shores were painted on [[Byōbu|folding screens]] known as "rough seas screens" (''ariso byōbu'').<ref>{{harvnb|Guth|p=47}}</ref>{{year missing|date=May 2018}}{{efn|A "rough sea screen" features in one of Hokusai's earliest works, [[:File:Segawa_Kikunojo_III_--_Hokusai.jpg|''Segawa Kikunojo III as Masamune's Daughter, Oren'']], printed over fifty years before the ''Great Wave''}} Hokusai drew many waves throughout his career; the genesis of the ''Great Wave'' can be traced back over thirty years. The combination of wave and mountain was inspired by an oil painting by [[Shiba Kōkan]], an artist strongly influenced by the [[Western art]], particularly Dutch paintings, he had seen at Nagasaki, the only port open to foreigners in this period.<ref name="Forrer 24">{{harvnb|Forrer|2003|pp=23–24}}</ref> Kōkan's ''A View of Seven-League Beach'' was executed in middle of 1796 and exhibited publicly at the [[Atago Shrine (Tokyo)|Atago shrine in Shiba]]. Hokusai's print ''Springtime at Enoshima'', which he contributed to ''The Willow Branch'' poetry anthology published in 1797, is clearly derived from Kōkan's work, although the wave in Hokusai's version rises noticeably higher.<ref name="Forrer 26">{{harvnb|Forrer|2003|p=26}}</ref>
{{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical |width=250 | title = | image1 = Kanagawa-oki Honmoku no zu.jpg | caption1 = ''Kanagawa-oki honmoku no zu'', print by Hokusai, {{circa|1803}} | image2 = Oshiokuri Hato Tsusen no Zu.jpg | caption2 = ''Oshiokuri hato tsūsen no zu'', print by Hokusai, {{circa|1805}} }}
Closer compositionally to the ''Great Wave'' are two previous prints by Hokusai: ''Kanagawa-oki Honmoku no zu'' ({{circa|1803}}) and ''Oshiokuri Hato Tsusen no Zu'', ({{circa|1805}})<ref>{{harvnb|Nagata|Bester|1999|p=40}}</ref> Both works have subjects identical to the ''Great Wave'': a sailboat and a rowboat respectively. In both precursor works, the subjects are in the midst of a storm, beneath a great wave that threatens to devour them. An analysis of the differences between the two works and the ''Great Wave'' demonstrates the artistic and technical development of Hokusai:<ref name="soundfury">{{cite web | url = http://thesoundsinsidemyhead.blogspot.com/2008/05/hokusais-great-wave.html | title = Hokusai's Great Wave | date = 2010-07-07 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110831012345/http://thesoundsinsidemyhead.blogspot.com/2008/05/hokusais-great-wave.html | archivedate = 2011-08-31 | df = }}</ref>
* In the earlier two designs the waves appear to be dense and uniform; they almost seem to be minerals. Their rigidity and verticality evoke the shape of a snow-capped mountain, while in the ''Great Wave'' the wave stands out because it is more active, dynamic, and aggressive, which makes it threatening. * The earlier images are very marked by the perspective traditionally used in Japanese painting, where the viewer sees the scene from a bird's-eye view. The ''Great Wave'', on the other hand, is depicted in a more western perspective, giving the feeling that the wave will break on top of the viewer. * In the earlier prints the horizon is in the middle, whereas in the ''Great Wave'' the horizon is so low that it forces the viewer's eye to the very center of the action. * In the first two, there is a sail boat on the crest of the wave, as if it had managed to escape. Hokusai eliminated this element for the ''Great Wave'', because it interfered with the dynamic of the curve or to make the image more dramatic. * The two first prints have an uneven composition, lacking consistency, whereas the ''Great Wave'' only has two important masses: the wave itself, and the vanishing point beneath the wave. * The wave shows the level of control that Hokusai had reached. The image, although simple in its design is, however, the result of a long process, a methodical reflection. The basis of this method were laid out by Hokusai in his 1812 work ''Quick lessons of simplified drawing,'' in which he explains that every object can be drawn using the relationship of the circle and square.
== Image ==
=== Description ===
This print is a [[List of ukiyo-e terms|''yoko-e'']], that is, a [[landscape format]] produced to the ''ōban'' size, about 25 cm high by 37 cm wide.<ref name="metmuseum">{{cite web | url = http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/JP1847 | title = Katsushika Hokusai: The Great Wave at Kanagawa | accessdate = 2010-07-07 | publisher = Metropolitan Museum of Art | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100614065800/http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/jp1847 | archivedate = 2010-06-14 | df = }}</ref>
The [[Composition (visual arts)|composition]] comprises three main elements: the sea whipped up by a storm, three boats and a mountain. It includes the signature in the upper left-hand corner.
==== The mountain ==== {{further|Mount Fuji}}
The mountain with a snow-capped peak is [[Mount Fuji]], which in Japan is considered sacred and a symbol of national identity,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fujiarts.com/cgi-bin/item.pl?item=56389 | title = Under the Wave off Kanagawa (The Great Wave) by Hokusai (1760–1849) | accessdate = 2010-07-10 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110711053740/http://www.fujiarts.com/cgi-bin/item.pl?item=56389 | archivedate = 2011-07-11 | df = }}</ref> as well as a symbol of beauty.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://web-japan.org/nipponia/nipponia35/es/topic/index.html | title = El Monte Fuji como Objeto Artístico |accessdate=7 July 2010 |language= Spanish|author=Nipponia}}</ref> Mount Fuji is an iconic figure in many Japanese representations of famous places (''[[meisho-e]]''), as is the case in Hokusai's series of ''[[Thirty-six Views of Mount Fuji]]'', which opens with the present scene.
The dark color around Mount Fuji seems to indicate that the scene occurs early in the morning, with the sun rising from behind the observer, illuminating the mountain's snowy peak. While [[cumulonimbus]] storm clouds seem to be hanging in the sky between the viewer and Mount Fuji, no rain is to be seen either in the foreground scene or on Mount Fuji, which itself appears completely cloudless.<ref name="royal">{{cite journal | last1=Cartwright| first1=HE | last2=Nakamura | first2=H | url= http://rsnr.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/early/2009/02/23/rsnr.2007.0039.full | title = What kind of a wave is Hokusai's Great wave off Kanagawa? | accessdate=7 July 2010 | journal=Notes and Records | volume=63 | issue=2 | pages=119–135 |doi=10.1098/rsnr.2007.0039 | year=2009 }}</ref>
==== Boats ==== In the scene there are three ''oshiokuri-bune'', fast boats that are used to transport live fish<ref>{{harvnb|Kobayashi|Harbison|1997|p=47}}.</ref> from the [[Izu Province|Izu]] and [[Bōsō Peninsula|Bōsō]] peninsulas to the markets of the [[Tokyo Bay|bay of Edo]]. As the name of the piece indicates the boats are in [[Kanagawa]] prefecture, with Tokyo to the north, Mt Fuji to the northwest, the bay of [[Sagami Bay|Sagami]] to the south and the bay of Tokyo to the east. The boats, oriented to the southeast, are returning to the capital.
There are eight rowers per boat, clinging to their oars. There are two more passengers in the front of each boat, bringing the total number of human figures in the image to thirty. Using the boats as reference, one can approximate the size of the wave: the ''oshiokuri-bune'' were generally between 12 and 15 meters long, and noting that Hokusai stretched the vertical scale by 30%, the wave must be between 10 and 12 meters tall.<ref name="royal" />
==== Sea and waves ==== {{multiple image | Table_Position = right | direction = vertical | width = 200 | Title = Detail of the waves. | image1 = The Great Wave off Kanagawa - wave.jpg | width1 = 200 | caption1 = Detail of the crest of the wave, looking like claws | image2 = Kanagawa-oki nami-ura - 2 waves or 2 Fuji.jpg | width2 = 200 | caption2 = Detail of the small wave, with similarity to the silhouette of Fuji }}
The sea dominates the composition as an extending wave about to break. In the moment captured in this image, the wave forms a circle around the center of the design, framing Mount Fuji in the background.
[[Edmond de Goncourt]] described the wave in this way:
{{quote|The drawing of the wave is a deification of the sea made by a painter who lived with the religious terror of the overwhelming ocean completely surrounding his country; He is impressed by the sudden fury of the ocean's leap toward the sky, by the deep blue of the inner side of the curve, by the splash of its claw-like crest as it sprays forth droplets.<ref name="radioUNAM">{{cite web | url = http://www.radiounam.unam.mx/site/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1130&Itemid=55 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110722230510/http://www.radiounam.unam.mx/site/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1130&Itemid=55 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 22 July 2011 | title = La Gran Ola de Kanagawa | accessdate = 7 July 2010 | language = Spanish | author = Radio UNAM | authorlink = Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México }}</ref>}}
Andreas Ramos, a writer, notes:
{{quote|... a seascape with Fuji. The waves form a frame through which we see the mountain. The gigantic wave is a ''yin'' ''yang'' of empty space beneath the mountain. The inevitable breaking that we await creates a tension in the picture. In the foreground, a small wave forming a miniature Fuji is reflected by the distant mountain, itself shrunk in perspective. The little wave is larger than the mountain. The small fishermen cling to thin fishing boats, slide on a sea-mount looking to dodge the wave. The violent ''Yang'' of nature is overcome by the ''yin'' of the confidence of these experienced fishermen. Strangely, despite a storm, the sun shines high.<ref name="radioUNAM" />}}
==== Signature ==== [[File:The Great Wave off Kanagawa - Title and signature.jpg|thumb|left|80px|Hokusai's signature]] ''The Great Wave off Kanagawa'' has two inscriptions. The first, within a rectangular cartouche in the top-left corner is the series title: "冨嶽三十六景/神奈川冲/浪裏" ''Fugaku Sanjūrokkei / Kanagawa oki / nami ura'', which translates as "Thirty-six Views of Mount Fuji / Offshore from Kanagawa / Beneath the wave". The second inscription, to the left, is the artist's signature: 北斎改爲一筆 ''Hokusai aratame Iitsu hitsu'', ("From the brush of Hokusai, changing his name to Iitsu").<ref name="Guimet1">{{cite web | url = http://www.guimet.fr/HOKUSAI-Mad-about-his-art-From | title = Hokusai "Mad about his art" from Edmond de Goncourt to Norbert Lagane | accessdate = 7 July 2010 | author = [[Guimet Museum]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101014144021/http://www.guimet.fr/HOKUSAI-Mad-about-his-art-From | archivedate = 14 October 2010 | df = }}</ref>
Over his career, Hokusai used more than 30 different names, always beginning a new cycle of works by changing it, and letting his students use the previous name.
In his work ''Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji'' he used four distinct signatures, changing it according to the phase of the work: ''Hokusai aratame Iitsu hitsu'', ''zen Hokusai Iitsu hitsu'', ''Hokusai Iitsu hitsu'' and ''zen saki no Hokusai Iitsu hitsu''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://expositions.bnf.fr/japonaises/grand/083.htm | title = Hokusai, Les Trente-six vues du mont Fuji |accessdate=7 July 2010 |language=French |author=[[Bibliothèque nationale de France]]}}</ref>
== Technique == [[File:Ukiyo-e dsc04680.jpg|thumb|right|Block used to produce woodblock prints]] In [[Japanese woodblock printing]] the artist's final preparatory sketch (''shita-e'') is taken to a ''horishi'', or block carver, who glues the thin ''[[washi]]'' paper to a block of wood, usually cherry,<ref name="metwoodblock">{{cite web | url =https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/ukiy/hd_ukiy.htm | title = Woodblock Prints in the Ukiyo-e Style |accessdate=2010-07-05 |publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]}}</ref> and then carefully carves it away to form a relief of the lines of the image.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.colombia.emb-japan.go.jp/cultura/061010.htm | title = Ukiyo-e, arte de grabado japonés | accessdate = 2010-07-11 | language = Spanish | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100419113623/http://www.colombia.emb-japan.go.jp/cultura/061010.htm | archivedate = 2010-04-19 | df = }}</ref> In the process, the drawing is lost. Finally, with all the necessary blocks (usually one for each color),<ref name="metwoodblock" /> a ''surishi'', or printer, who places the printing paper on each block consecutively and rubs the back with a hand-tool known as a ''[[Baren (printing tool)|baren]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.lagranepoca.com/articles/2010/05/22/4615.html | title = Ukiyo-e: Imágenes del mundo flotante | accessdate = 2010-07-11 | language = Spanish | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101210013416/http://www.lagranepoca.com/articles/2010/05/22/4615.html | archivedate = 2010-12-10 | df = }}</ref> There could be a great number of impressions produced, sometimes thousands, before the blocks wore out.<ref name="metwoodblock" />
Because of the nature of the production process, the final work was usually the result of a collaboration in which the painter generally did not participate in the production of the prints.<ref name="guimet2">{{cite web | url = http://www.guimet.fr/Masterpieces-from-the-Ota-Memorial?var_recherche=Hokusai | title = Masterpieces from the Ota Memorial museum of Art Paintings and Japanese prints | accessdate = 2010-07-05 | year = 2005 | publisher = [[Musée Guimet]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110720034557/http://www.guimet.fr/Masterpieces-from-the-Ota-Memorial?var_recherche=Hokusai | archivedate = 2011-07-20 | df = }}</ref>
The design uses only a small number of different color blocks. The water is rendered with three shades of blue;{{efn|In early prints of the ''Great Wave'' the key-block, usually only used for outlines, is simultaneously used to print the dark-blue areas of the waves.}} the boats are yellow;{{efn|The pale red seen on the sides of two of the boats in the frequently reproduced Metropolitan Museum print (JP 1847) has apparently been added by hand.<ref name=bm/>}} a dark grey for the sky behind Fuji and on the boat immediately below; a pale grey in the sky above Fuji and on the foreground boat; pink clouds at the top of the image. "The block for these pink clouds seems to have been slightly abraded along parts of the edge to give a subtle gradated effect (''ita-bokashi'')".<ref name=bm>Clark (2001)</ref>
Even though no law of [[intellectual property]] existed in Japan before the [[Meiji era]], there was still a sense of ownership and rights with respect to the blocks from which the prints were produced.{{efn|The concept of rights concerned with woodblock ownership was known as ''zōhan''.}} Rather than belonging to the artist, the blocks were considered the property of the ''hanmoto'' (publisher) or ''honya'' (publisher/bookseller) who could do with them as he wished. In some cases the blocks were sold or transferred to other publishers, in which case they became known as ''kyūhan''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.viewingjapaneseprints.net/texts/topictexts/faq/faq_original.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080327112545/http://www.viewingjapaneseprints.net/texts/topictexts/faq/faq_original.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2008-03-27 | title = Viewing Japanese Prints: What Is an Original Woodblock Print? | accessdate = 2010-07-06 | publisher = ''Viewing Japanese Prints'' }}</ref>
==Impressions== [[File:Great Wave, British Museum 1937,0710,0.147.png|thumb|upright|A later impression of the ''Great Wave'' with characteristic darker sky.<br>[[British Museum]] (1937,0710,0.147)]] Given that the series was very popular when it was produced, printing continued until the woodblocks started to show significant wear. It is likely that the original woodblocks printed around 5,000 copies.<ref name="Private Life">{{cite web |last1=Society |first1=Infocobuild |title=Private Life of a Masterpiece: Episode 14 - Katsushika Hokusai: The Great Wave |url=http://www.infocobuild.com/books-and-films/art/PrivateLifeMasterpiece/episode-14.html |website=www.infocobuild.com |language=en|editor=[[BBC]]}}</ref> Given that many impressions have been lost, in wars, earthquakes, fires and other natural disasters, few early impressions survive in which the lines of the woodblocks were still sharp at the time of printing.<ref name="Private Life" /> The remaining prints and subsequent reproductions vary considerably in quality and condition.<ref name=wsj/>
Later impressions typically have a darker grey sky, and can be identified by a break in the line of the wave behind the boat on the right.<ref name=bm/>
The highest price paid for a ''Great Wave'' print in a public sale is a relatively low $160,000. Hokusai's auction record is nearly $1.5 million as of 2012.<ref name=wsj>{{cite news|work=The Wall Street Journal|title=How Hokusai’s ‘The Great Wave’ Went Viral|date=March 18, 2015|first=Ellen|last= Gamerman|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-hokusais-the-great-wave-went-viral-1426698151}}</ref> The print owned by the British Museum cost £130,000 in 2008 and is only on display for six months every five years to prevent fading.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sooke |first1=Alastair |title=Katsushika Hokusai: the starving artist who became the prince of tides |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/art/artists/katsushika-hokusai-starving-artist-became-prince-tides/ |website=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=22 October 2018}}</ref>
== Influence == {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical |width=200 |image1=L62 - Musée Rodin - Camile Claudel - La Vague.JPG |caption1=''La Vague'' by Camile Claudel (1897) | image2 = Debussy - La Mer - The great wave of Kanaga from Hokusai.jpg | caption2= Cover of Debussy's ''La mer'' (1905) }}
{{expand section|date=January 2017}} The print is one of the most reproduced and most instantly recognized artworks in the world.<ref name=wsj/>
Following the [[Meiji Restoration]] in 1868, Japan ended a long period of national isolation and became open to imports from [[Western world|the West]]. In turn, much Japanese art came to Europe and America and quickly gained popularity. The influence of Japanese art on Western culture became known as [[Japonism]]. Japanese woodblock prints became a source of inspiration for artists in many genres, particularly the [[Impressionism|Impressionists]]. Hokusai was seen as the emblematic Japanese artist and images from his prints and books influenced many different works.
[[Vincent van Gogh]], a great admirer of Hokusai, praised the quality of drawing and use of line in the ''Great Wave'', and said it had a terrifying emotional impact.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vangoghletters.org/vg/letters/let676/letter.html|title=Letter 676: To Theo van Gogh. Arles, Saturday, 8 September 1888|publisher=Van Gogh Museum}}</ref>
French sculptor [[Camille Claudel]]'s ''La Vague'' (1897) replaces the boats in Hokusai's ''Great Wave'' with sea-nymphs.
The image inspired [[Claude Debussy]]'s orchestral work, ''[[La mer (Debussy)|La mer]]'', and appeared on the cover of the score's first edition published by [[Auguste Durand#A. Durand .26 fils|A. Durand & Fils]] in 1905.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/blogs/now-at-the-met/2014/debussy-la-mer |title= Hokusai and Debussy's Evocations of the Sea|date=July 22, 2014 |first=Michael|last= Cirigliano II|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art}}</ref>
[[Indigenous Australian]] artist [[Lin Onus]] used the ''Great Wave'' as the basis for his 1992 painting ''Michael and I are just slipping down the pub for a minute''.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ashcroft|first=Bill|date=2013-07-26|title=Hybridity and Transformation: The Art of Lin Onus|url=http://postcolonial.org/index.php/pct/article/view/1706|journal=Postcolonial Text|language=en|volume=8|issue=1}}</ref>
An artistic work named ''Uprisings'' by Japanese/American Artist [[Kozyndan]] is based on the print, with the foam of the wave being replaced by bunnies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kozyndan.com/art/uprisings|title=Uprisings – Kozyndan|website=kozyndan.com}}</ref>
Apple [[macOS]] and [[iOS]] display a small version of the ''Great Wave'' as the image for the Water Wave emoji.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://emojipedia.org/water-wave/ | title = Water Wave Emoji | publisher = [[Emojipedia]] | accessdate = 2014-10-29}}</ref>
The logo used by the [[Quiksilver]] clothing company was inspired by the woodcut.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lexpress.fr/informations/surf-la-planche-a-billets_638908.html |title=Surf La planche à billet |accessdate=2009-09-06 |author=(In French) [[L'Express (France)|L'Express]] |date=13 July 2000 |work= |publisher=}}</ref>
In the card game ''[[Magic: The Gathering]]'', two cards reference ''The Great Wave off Kanagawa'' in their artwork: Rampant Growth and Kiora, The Crashing Wave.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
The image is featured on a limited mintage 2017 legal tender coin for the [[Republic of Fiji]], as created by Scottsdale Mint.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apmex.com/product/104139/2017-fiji-great-wave-proof-silver-coin-colorized|title=2017 Fiji Great Wave Proof Silver Coin (Colorized)|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022091014/http://www.apmex.com/product/104139/2017-fiji-great-wave-proof-silver-coin-colorized|archivedate=2016-10-22|df=}}</ref>
The image (reversed and recolorized) is featured on [[Kitchens of Distinction]]'s album ''[[Strange Free World]]''.
A popular internet parody of the image, titled "Sea is for Cookie", was created for a [[Reddit]] [[Adobe Photoshop]] competition. The piece features the wave with [[googly eyes]] and cookies in the crest, resembling [[Cookie Monster]] eating cookies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://laughingsquid.com/sea-is-for-cookie-a-mashup-of-cookie-monster-and-the-great-wave-off-kanagawa/ |title=Sea Is for Cookie, A Mashup of Cookie Monster and 'The Great Wave off Kanagawa' |last=Streams |first=Kimber |website= [[Laughing Squid]] |date= 2014-01-24 |accessdate= 2018-02-27}}</ref>
== On screen == The print is the subjects of two art documentary series : * ''La Menace suspendue'', ''[[Palettes]]'' by [[Alain Jaubert]] (France, 1999). * ''The Great Wave'', ''[[The Private Life of a Masterpiece]]'' ([[BBC]], 2004). It details the fascination surrounding the work in the East and West, its influence, and the artist's insights into a number of different areas, as revealed through the work.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fulmartv.co.uk/PLMasterpiece10.shtml | title = 'The Great Wave' by Hokusai | publisher = Fulmartv.co.uk | date = 2004-04-17 | accessdate = 2010-07-04 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100722005321/http://www.fulmartv.co.uk/PLMasterpiece10.shtml | archivedate = 2010-07-22 | df = }}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = UNFRAME | type = [[Cooperative]] | foundation = 2013 | logo = Logo Unframe.jpg | founder = Riccardo Budini | location = [[Rome]] [[Italy]] | key_people = Mstyslav Chernov, Alexandros Demetriades, Juan Herrero, Riccardo Budini | area_served = [[World]]wide | industry = [[Photography]] | products = [[Photojournalism]], [[photo agency]] | homepage = [http://www.unframe.com/ unframe.com] }} '''UnFrame''' collective is an independent resource of documentary photography exclusively managed by an international group of photographers dedicated to shining the spotlight on social, political and everyday issues that surround us. The collective was founded in February 2013 with the aim of developing and working on both long term social and political issues with a deeper perspective in addition to responding to news events as they happen anywhere in the world.
== Documented events == In 2013, during the first year of its activity, events documented were:
* The [[Rana Plaza]] building collapse in [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]]. * The [[2013 protests in Turkey]]. * The consequences on civilians of the troubled political season in [[Bangladesh]]. * The [[Ukraine]] political crisis, the Kiev revolution ([[Euromaidan]]) and the Russian occupation of Crimea.
== Issues == The photographers have organized a collective archive of long term issues. Amongst others are the following:
* The aftermath of the [[Arab Spring]] in [[North Africa]] and the [[Middle East]]. * Three years of civil unrest and economic hardship in [[Italy]]. * The social consequences of the political division of [[Cyprus]]. * The social conditions of the [[Romani people|Roma]] in Europe.
Starting from September 2013 UnFrame self manages the collectives' growing archives in order to best facilitate the syndication of its work in the most efficient way possible. To this effect it has also partnered with key resource media outlets allowing for the distribution of its photographs including the French photo agency Cosmos.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|unframe.com}} * [https://www.facebook.com/unframephoto Facebook page]

{{Infobox artist | name = Yuri Mikhailovich Shablikin | image = | imagesize = 200px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = October 31, 1932 | birth_place = [[Leningrad]], USSR | death_date = | death_place = | field = Painting, [[Graphics]], [[Conservation-restoration|Restoration]] | citizenship = USSR, [[Russian Federation]] | nationality = | training = [[Vera Mukhina Institute]] | movement = [[Realism (visual art)|Realism]] | works = | patrons = | awards = }}
'''Yuri Mikhailovich Shablikin''' ({{lang-ru|Ю́рий Миха́йлович Шаблы́кин}}; October 31, 1932, [[Leningrad]], USSR) was a Soviet, Russian realist painter, graphic artist, restorer, art teacher, who live and work in Saint Petersburg, a member of the [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] (before 1992 - the Leningrad branch of Union of Artists of Russian Federation),<ref>''Directory of Members of the Union of Artists of USSR. Volume 2.''- Moscow: Soviet artist, 1979. - p.565.</ref> regarded by art historian Sergei V. Ivanov as one of representatives of the [[Leningrad School of Painting|Leningrad school of painting]].<ref>''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.''- Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – pp.19, 100, 373, 390, 393, 394, 396, 398, 399, 401, 404, 406, 415-420, 422-424, 443.</ref>
== Biography == '''Yuri Mikhailovich Shablikin''' was born October 31, 1932, in the Leningrad, USSR.
In 1955 Yuri Shablikin graduated from the [[Vera Mukhina Institute|Leningrad Higher School of Industrial Art named after Vera Mukhina]] where he studied under Vasily Ushakov, [[Gleb Savinov]], Ivan Stepashkin, Lija Ostrova, Alexander Kazantsev.
Since 1956 Yuri Shablikin has participated in art exhibitions. He painted landscapes, still lifes, portraits, genre scenes, worked in eseal and monumental painting and as restorer of painting. He exhibited his works in [[Leningrad]] in 1976, and in [[Nyandoma]] ([[Arkhangelsk Oblast|Arkhangelsk Province]]) in 1986.
Yuri Shablikin most famous for his lyrical landscapes devoted to nature and the life of the northern Russian countryside. For example, he made a lot of paintings about [[Shozhma River]] and [[Shozhma]] village. He paint his works mostly from the memory, creating the artistic equivalent of his deeply personal perception of nature. At the Russian North he has found not only his own motives, but also a special silver range of colours, which are characteristic of these places and become the feature of his paintings.
Yuri Shablikin is a member of the [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] since 1960. In the years 1950-1960, he taught at the Department of General Painting at the [[Vera Mukhina Institute|Leningrad Higher School of Industrial Art named after Vera Mukhina.]]
His paintings reside in museums and private collections in Russia, Germany, France, England, the U.S., Italy, and others.
==See also== * [[Leningrad School of Painting]] * [[List of painters of Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] * [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]]
